phenoscope.core.accessors package

phenoscope.core.accessors package¶

Module contents¶

Overview¶

The accessors submodule provides a comprehensive set of tools and interfaces for accessing and interacting with the various data components of an image. These components range from raw pixel data and matrix representations to object masks, metadata, and high-level measurements. Additionally, it includes utilities that streamline development workflows involving image processing and analysis.

The goal is to provide efficient, standardized access to image data while enabling intuitive and flexible integration for advanced image manipulation and analysis tasks.

Image Data Containers¶

This category includes classes designed to offer fundamental abstractions for accessing image data in various representations:

  1. ImageArray

    Represents the multichannel pixel data of an image when provided. Useful for direct manipulation and pixel-wise operations.

  2. ImageMatrix

    Provides structured access to the image in its matrix form, offering methods suited for mathematical or analytical operations on image data. Automatically converted from RGB using weighted luminance conversion.

  3. ImageEnhancedMatrix

    An enhanceable copy of the image matrix to improve detection while maintaining the original image data integrity.

Objects and Object Mapping¶

These classes manage object-level abstractions and their corresponding data mappings:

  1. ObjectMap

    Represents a mapping of detected objects or regions in the image to their associated IDs. Useful for:

    • Object identification

    • Bounding box management

    • Spatial relationships between objects.

    • Region-based calculations

  2. ObjectMask

    An abstract specialized for working with binary masks of objects. Useful for morphological operations such as erosion, dilation, and closing.

    Note:

    Changes to the object mask will cause relabeling of the object map

High-Level Object Interfaces¶

These classes provide consolidated access to manage multiple object-level and metadata components.

  1. ImageObjects

    Facilitates high-level interaction with detected objects within an image. Features include:

    • Feature extraction

    • Object comparison

    • Visualization of detected objects

  2. MeasurementContainer (Coming Soon!)

    Encapsulates measurements or attributes associated with objects, such as size, shape, or intensity. Organizes measurements for reproducibility and easier analysis.

  3. MetadataContainer (Coming Soon!)

    Responsible for storing and accessing metadata associated with the image. Examples of metadata include:

    • Acquisition details

    • Resolution

    • Additional contextual information.

HSV (Hue, Saturation, Brightness) Interface¶

1. HsvAccessor Provides detailed access to the HSV (Hue, Saturation, Brightness) color space components of an image. This abstract includes support for:

  • Direct pixel access via __getitem__ and __setitem__.

  • Advanced utilities for image visualization and object-specific manipulation in the HSV domain.

Key Methods:

  • shape: Returns the dimensions of the HSV representation.

  • copy: Creates and returns a full copy of the HSV data structure.

  • histogram: Computes a histogram for the HSV image or parts of it.

  • show: Displays the HSV image.

  • show_objects: Visualizes objects overlaid on the HSV image.

  • extract_obj_hue, extract_obj_saturation, extract_obj_brightness, extract_obj:

Extract specific HSV component data for individual image objects, aiding in targeted color-based analysis.

Purpose and Use Cases¶

The accessors submodule is designed for developers and researchers working on advanced image processing tasks. It is particularly suited for:

  • Object detection and feature extraction

  • HSV color-space analysis

  • Grid Analysis

  • Metadata association for image datasets

  • Advanced mathematical and matrix operations on image data.

class phenoscope.core.accessors.GridAccessor(parent_image: GridImage)[source]¶

Bases: object

An accessor for managing and interacting with a structured grid data in an Image.

This class provides methods and properties to access and manipulate grid dimensions, retrieve grid edges, sections, rows, columns, maps, and overlays, as well as perform calculations across the grid. It is designed to work with a handler, which manages the core image data and computational aspects.

The primary responsibilities of this class include managing grid rows and columns, calculating linear regression information for rows and columns, and creating visual representations of the grid layout with object maps.

Parameters:

parent_image (GridImage) – An object that interacts with and provides the necessary data and tools for managing the grid, including methods and attributes related to grid structure, objects, and data.

_parent_image¶

The parent GridImage object managing the grid data, objects, and operations.

Type:

GridImage

nrows¶

Number of rows in the grid.

Type:

int

ncols¶

Number of columns in the grid.

Type:

int

_idx_ref_matrix¶

A matrix of grid positions used for indexing.

Type:

class phenoscope.core.accessors.HsvAccessor(parent_image: Image)[source]¶

Bases: object

A accessor class to handle and analyze HSV (Hue, Saturation, Value) image data efficiently.

This class provides functionality for accessing and processing HSV image data. Users can retrieve components (hue, saturation, brightness) of the image, generate visual histograms of color distributions, and measure specific object properties masked within the HSV image.

Extensive visualization methods are also included, allowing display of HSV components and their masked variations. This class is ideal for image analysis tasks where color properties play a significant role.

Parameters:

parent_image (Image)

_parent_image¶

The parent Image object that manages image data and operations.

Type:

Image

copy() → ndarray[source]¶

Returns a copy of the image array

Return type:

ndarray

extract_obj(bg_color: int = 0)[source]¶

Extracts the object hue, saturation, and brightness from the HSV image. With the background elements set to 0

Parameters:

bg_color (int)

extract_obj_brightness(bg_color: int = 0, normalized: bool = False)[source]¶

Extracts the object brightness from the HSV image.

Note

  • Unnormalized Range: 0-255 (Same as OpenCV)

  • Normalized Range: 0-1

Parameters:

  • normalized (bool)

  • Normalized Range: 0-1

histogram(figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 5), linewidth=1)[source]¶

Generates and displays histograms for hue, saturation, and brightness components of an image, alongside the original image. The histograms depict the distribution of these components, and this analysis can aid in understanding the image’s color properties.

Parameters:

  • figsize (Tuple[int, int]) – The size of the figure that contains all subplots, specified as a tuple of width and height in inches.

  • linewidth (int) – The width of the lines used in the histograms.

Returns:

A tuple containing the Matplotlib figure object and an ndarray

of axes, where the axes correspond to the subplots.

Return type:

Tuple[Figure, ndarray]

show(figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 8), title: str = None, shrink=0.2)[source]¶

Displays the Hue, Saturation, and Brightness (HSV components) of the given image data in a visualization using subplots. Each subplot corresponds to one of the HSV channels, and color bars are included to help interpret the values.

A color map is used for better visual distinction, with ‘hsv’ for Hue, ‘viridis’ for Saturation, and grayscale for Brightness. Provides an optional title for the entire figure and flexibility in the sizing and shrink factor of color bars.

Parameters:

  • figsize (Tuple[int, int]) – Size of the figure in inches as a (width, height) tuple. Defaults to (10, 8).

  • title (str) – Title of the entire figure. If None, no title will be set.

  • shrink (float) – Shrink factor for the color bar size displayed next to subplots. Defaults to 0.6.

Returns:

A tuple containing the created figure and axes for further customization or display.

Return type:

Tuple[plt.Figure, plt.Axes]

show_objects(figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 8), title: str = None, shrink=0.6)[source]¶

Displays the Hue, Saturation, and Brightness (HSV components) of the given image data in a visualization using subplots. Each subplot corresponds to one of the HSV channels, and color bars are included to help interpret the values.

A color map is used for better visual distinction, with ‘hsv’ for Hue, ‘viridis’ for Saturation, and grayscale for Brightness. Provides an optional title for the entire figure and flexibility in the sizing and shrink factor of color bars.

Parameters:

  • figsize (Tuple[int, int]) – Size of the figure in inches as a (width, height) tuple. Defaults to (10, 8).

  • title (str) – Title of the entire figure. If None, no title will be set.

  • shrink (float) – Shrink factor for the color bar size displayed next to subplots. Defaults to 0.6.

Returns:

A tuple containing the created figure and axes for further customization or display.

Return type:

Tuple[plt.Figure, plt.Axes]

class phenoscope.core.accessors.ImageArray(parent_image: Image)[source]¶

Bases: object

This class represents an accessor for handling image arrays with helper methods for accessing, modifying, visualizing, and analyzing the multichannel image data. It relies on the parent image handler object that serves as the bridge to the underlying image array and associated metadata or attributes.

The class allows users to interact with image arrays intuitively while providing features such as advanced visualization (both for the raw images and their derived representations, like histograms or overlays). Through its properties and methods, users can explore, manipulate, and analyze the structural or geometrical attributes of the image and its segmented objects.

Key use cases for this class include displaying selected channels or the entire image (including overlays and highlighted objects), generating channel-specific histograms, and accessing image data attributes, such as shape.

Parameters:

parent_image (Image)

_parent_image¶

An internal attribute referring to the parent Image object that mediates interactions with the underlying image array, properties (shape, name, schema), and associated object maps or labels.

__getitem__(key) → ndarray[source]¶

Returns a copy of the elements at the subregion specified by the given key.

This class provides a mechanism for extracting a specific subregion from the multichannel image array. The extracted subregion is represented in the form of a NumPy array and its indexable nature allows users to freely interact with the underlying array data.

Returns:

A copy of the extracted subregion represented as a NumPy array.

Return type:

np.ndarray

__setitem__(key, value)[source]¶

Represents an exception that occurs when an illegal assignment is attempted on the images array. Use Image.set_image() to change image array data.

Raises:

C_ImageArraySubhandler.IllegalElementAssignmentError – Raised when an illegal element assignment is attempted within the image array subhandler.

histogram(figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 5), linewidth: int = 1) → Tuple[Figure, ndarray][source]¶

Generates histograms for each channel of the image represented in the provided handler and visualizes them along with the original image. It supports RGB and non-RGB image schemas by adjusting the channel histograms accordingly. The method plots the original image and histograms for three channels side by side, customizing titles to correspond to the image schema (e.g., RGB or other channels).

Parameters:

  • figsize (Tuple[int, int]) – Tuple representing the figure size (width, height) for the plot layout. Defaults to (10, 5).

  • linewidth (int) – Width of the lines used in the histogram plots. Defaults to 1.

Returns:

A tuple where the first element is the figure

containing the visualized plots (original image and histograms). The second element is the array of axes represented by subplots.

Return type:

Tuple[plt.Figure, np.ndarray]

show(channel: int | None = None, ax: plt.Axes = None, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 5), title: str = None)[source]¶

Display the image array with matplotlib.

Parameters:

  • channel (Optional[int]) – (Optional[int]) The channel number to display. If None, shows the combination of all channels

  • ax (plt.Axes) – (plt.Axes) Axes object to use for plotting.

  • figsize (Tuple[int, int]) – (Tuple[int, int]): Figure size in inches.

  • title (str) – (str) a title for the plot

matplotlib figure and axes object

tuple(plt.Figure, plt.Axes)

show_objects(channel: int | None = None, bg_color: int = 0, cmap: str = 'gray', ax: plt.Axes = None, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 5), title: str = None)[source]¶

Displays segmented objects in an image minus the background, enabling visual analysis of segmentation quality. The function provides customization options for displaying specific channels, modifying background color, and adjusting axes and figure settings. The segmented objects can be separated by channels with respective colormap, or the entire image can be displayed if no specific channel is provided. This visualization can help examine segmentations overlayed on image arrays.

Parameters:

  • channel (Optional[int]) – The specific channel of the image to display. If None, the entire image across all channels is displayed.

  • bg_color (int) – The background pixel value to be rendered for unsegmented areas in the displayed image.

  • cmap (str) – The colormap to apply to the image representation when a specific channel is displayed.

  • ax (plt.Axes) – The axes object to draw the visualization. If None, a new matplotlib Axes object is created.

  • figsize (Tuple[int, int]) – The size of the figure in inches (width, height). Applicable when ax is None.

  • title (str) – Optional title for the plot displayed on the axes. If None, defaults to the name of the image handler.

Returns:

A tuple containing the matplotlib Figure and

Axes objects used for rendering the visualization.

Return type:

Tuple[plt.Figure, plt.Axes]

show_overlay(object_label: int | None = None, ax: plt.Axes = None, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 5), annotate: bool = False, annotation_size: int = 12, annotation_color: str = 'white', annotation_facecolor: str = 'red')[source]¶

Displays an overlay visualization of a labeled object map overlaid on the original image.

Allows for optional annotation of object labels in the visualization with configurable annotation styles. The visualization can be rendered on a new Matplotlib figure or an existing axis provided by the user.

Parameters:

  • object_label (Optional[int]) – The specific label of the object to remove from the overlay visualization. If None, all labels will appear in the overlay.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – The Matplotlib axis on which to render the visualization. If None, a new axis will be created.

  • figsize (Tuple[int, int]) – The size of the figure for the new axis, specified as a tuple. Ignored if ax is provided.

  • annotate (bool) – A flag indicating whether to annotate the object labels on the visualization.

  • annotation_size (int) – The font size of the annotation text displaying object labels.

  • annotation_color (str) – The color of the annotation text.

  • annotation_facecolor (str) – The background color of the annotation text boxes.

Returns:

A tuple where the first element is the Matplotlib figure

and the second element is the axis used for the overlay visualization.

Return type:

Tuple[plt.Figure, plt.Axes]

property shape: tuple[int, ...] | None¶

Returns the shape of the image

class phenoscope.core.accessors.ImageEnhancedMatrix(parent_image: Image)[source]¶

Bases: object

An accessor class to an image’s enhanced matrix which is a copy of the original image matrix that is preprocessed for enhanced detection.

Provides functionalities to manipulate and visualize the image enhanced matrix. This includes retrieving and setting data, resetting the matrix, visualizing histograms, viewing the matrix with overlays, and accessing matrix properties. The class relies on a handler for matrix operations and object mapping.

Parameters:

parent_image (Image) – The ImageHandler instance that contains the image enhanced matrix.

_parent_image¶

The Image instance that contains the image enhanced matrix and related data.

Type:

Image

__getitem__(key) → ndarray[source]¶

Provides a method to retrieve a copy of a specific portion of a parent image’s detection matrix based on the given key.

Parameters:

key – The index or slice used to access a specific part of the parent image’s detection matrix.

Returns:

A copy of the corresponding portion of the parent image’s detection

matrix.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

__setitem__(key, value)[source]¶

Sets a value in the detection matrix of the parent image for the provided key.

The method updates or sets a value in the detection matrix of the parent image (_parent_image._det_matrix) at the specified key. It ensures that if the value is not of type int, float, or bool, its shape matches the shape of the existing value at the specified key. If the shape does not match, ArrayKeyValueShapeMismatchError is raised. When the value is successfully set, the object map (omap) of the parent image is reset.

Parameters:

  • key – The key in the detection matrix where the value will be set.

  • value – The value to be assigned to the detection matrix. Must be of type int, float, or bool, or must have a shape matching the existing array in the detection matrix for the provided key.

Raises:

ArrayKeyValueShapeMismatchError – If the value is an array and its shape does not match the shape of the existing value in _parent_image._det_matrix for the specified key.

copy() → ndarray[source]¶

Returns a copy of the Detection Matrix.

Return type:

ndarray

class phenoscope.core.accessors.ImageMatrix(parent_image: Image)[source]¶

Bases: object

An accessor for managing and visualizing image matrix data. This is the greyscale representation converted using weighted luminance

This class provides a set of tools to access image data, analyze it through histograms, and visualize results. The class utilizes a parent Image object to interact with the underlying matrix data while maintaining immutability for direct external modifications. Additionally, it supports overlaying annotations and labels on the image for data analysis purposes.

Parameters:

parent_image (Image)

_parent_image¶

The parent image handler object that manages the image matrix and associated data.

Type:

ImageHandler

__getitem__(key)[source]¶

Provides the ability to access and return a copy of an internal matrix element from the parent image using key-based indexing.

Parameters:

key – The index or slice used to access the corresponding element in the parent image’s matrix.

Returns:

A copy of the matrix element or slice of the parent image’s internal matrix corresponding to the provided key.

__init__(parent_image: Image)[source]¶

Initiallizes the ImageMatrixSubhandler object.

Parameters:

parent_image (Image) – (Image) The parent ImageHandler that the ImageMatrixSubhandler belongs to.

__setitem__(key, value)[source]¶

Handles operations for managing and assigning sub-elements in an image matrix. The image matrix should be changed through the Image.set_images() method.

Raises:

  • C_ImageMatrixSubhandler.IllegalElementAssignmentError – If an attempt is made to

  • assign an invalid element to the image matrix. –

copy() → ndarray[source]¶

Returns a copy of the matrix from the parent image.

This method retrieves a copy of the parent image matrix, ensuring that modifications to the returned matrix do not affect the original data in the parent image’s matrix.

Returns:

A deep copy of the parent image matrix.

Return type:

np.ndarray

histogram(figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 5)) → Tuple[Figure, ndarray][source]¶

Generates a 2x2 subplot figure that includes the parent image and its grayscale histogram.

This method creates a subplot layout with 2 rows and 2 columns. The first subplot displays the parent image. The second subplot displays the grayscale histogram associated with the same image.

Parameters:

figsize (Tuple[int, int]) – A tuple specifying the width and height of the created figure in inches. Default value is (10, 5).

Returns:

Returns a matplotlib Figure object containing

the subplots and a NumPy array of axes for further customization.

Return type:

Tuple[plt.Figure, np.ndarray]

show(ax: plt.Axes = None, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = None, cmap: str = 'gray', title: str = None)[source]¶

Displays the matrix form of the image using matplotlib with various customizable options.

This function visualizes an image associated with the instance, leveraging matplotlib. It provides flexibility in terms of figure size, colormap, axis title, and a predefined matplotlib axis. It is designed to simplify image visualization while allowing users to control specific display parameters.

Parameters:

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – The matplotlib axis on which to plot. If no axis is provided, a new figure and axis are created. Defaults to None.

  • figsize (Tuple[int, int], optional) – Size of the figure in inches for the new axis. Ignored if ax is provided. Defaults to (6, 4) if not specified.

  • cmap (str) – Colormap to be applied for rendering the image. Defaults to the ‘gray’ colormap.

  • title (str, optional) – Title for the image. If provided, displays the specified title above the axis. Defaults to None.

Returns:

A tuple containing the matplotlib figure (if created)

and axis. The returned objects can be used for further customization outside this function.

Return type:

Tuple[plt.Figure, plt.Axes]

show_overlay(object_label: int | None = None, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = None, annotate: bool = False, annotation_size: int = 12, annotation_color: str = 'white', annotation_facecolor: str = 'red', ax: plt.Axes = None)[source]¶

isplays an overlay of labeled objects on the parent image, optionally with annotations.

Parameters:

  • object_label (Optional[int]) – If specified, the overlay will exclude the provided object label.

  • figsize (Tuple[int, int], optional) – Size of the figure to create if no axis is provided.

  • annotate (bool) – Whether to annotate the image objects. Defaults to False.

  • annotation_size (int) – Font size for annotations. Defaults to 12.

  • annotation_color (str) – Font color for annotations. Defaults to ‘white’.

  • annotation_facecolor (str) – Background color behind the annotation text. Defaults to ‘red’.

  • ax (plt.Axes, optional) – Axis to draw the overlay on. If not provided, a new matplotlib axis is created.

Returns:

The matplotlib figure and axes objects containing the overlay plot.

Return type:

Tuple[plt.Figure, plt.Axes]

class phenoscope.core.accessors.ImageObjects(parent_image: Image)[source]¶

Bases: object

An abstract for accessing image objects and provides various utilities for interacting with labeled objects in an image.

This class provides methods to retrieve information about labeled objects, interact with object properties, and manipulate the image analysis target. It supports operations such as accessing object labels, obtaining region properties, slicing specific objects, and calculating object details. It interacts with image labeling and analysis tools like skimage.regionprops.

Parameters:

parent_image (Image)

_parent_image¶

The handler object that manages the image data, including labeled object mappings and raw intensity matrices.

Type:

Handler

__getitem__(index: int) → Image[source]¶

Returns a slice of the object image based on the object’s index.

Parameters:

index (int)

Return type:

Image

Returns the index of the object with the given label from a sorted array of object labels.

Returns a slice of the object image based on the object’s index.

Parameters:

index (int)

Return type:

Image

info() → DataFrame[source]¶

Returns a pandas.DataFrame containing basic information about each object’s label, bounds, and centroid in the image.

This is useful for joining measurements across different tables.

Return type:

DataFrame

label_table() → Series[source]¶

Returns a consistently named pandas.Series containing the label number for each object in the image. Useful as an index for joining different measurements

(Image) The cropped bounding box of an object as an Image

Return type:

Image

reset()[source]¶

Resets the image object map such that the analysis target is the entire image.

property labels: List[str]¶

Returns the labels in the image. If no objects are in the image, returns a list with a single element of 1.

Note

  • The returned list of 1 represents that the entire image is the analysis target. This is to ensure consistency with the skimage.regionprops output and other measurements.

property num_objects: int¶

Returns the number of objects in the map.

property props¶

Returns a list of skimage.regionprops object for each of image’s objects. Useful for simple calculations.

Returns:

A list of properties for all

regions in the provided image.

Return type:

list[skimage.measure._regionprops.RegionProperties]

property slices¶

Returns a list of image slices for each object in the image

class phenoscope.core.accessors.ObjectMap(handler)[source]¶

Bases: object

ObjectMap stores an array with the pixel coordinates of each object and syncs changes with the ObjectMap class.

Note

Changes to the linked ObjectMask array will reset the labeling of the ObjectMap objects.

__getitem__(key)[source]¶

Returns a copy of the object_map of the image. If there are no objects, this is a matrix with all values set to 1 and the same shape as the iamge matrix.

__init__(handler)[source]¶
Parameters:

  • handler – (ImageHandler) The image handler that the ObjectMap belongs to.

  • preset_map – (np.ndarray[np.uint32]) Allows a way to easily create new Map components by allowing preset_map

__setitem__(key, value)[source]¶

Uncompresses the csc array & changes the values at the specified coordinates before recompressing the object map array.

copy() → ndarray[source]¶

Returns a copy of the object_map.

Return type:

ndarray

relabel()[source]¶

Relables all the objects based on their connectivity

reset() → None[source]¶

Resets the object_map to an empty map array with no objects in it.

Return type:

None

show(ax=None, figsize=None, cmap='gray', title=None) -> (<class 'matplotlib.figure.Figure'>, <class 'matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes'>)[source]¶

Display the object_map with matplotlib.

Parameters:

  • ax – (plt.Axes) Axes object to use for plotting.

  • figsize – (Tuple[int, int]): Figure size in inches.

  • cmap – (str, optional) Colormap to use.

  • title – (str) a title for the plot

Returns:

matplotlib figure and axes object

Return type:

tuple(plt.Figure, plt.Axes)

to_coo() → coo_matrix[source]¶

Returns a copy of the object map in COOrdinate format or ijv matrix

Return type:

coo_matrix

to_csc() → csc_matrix[source]¶

Returns a copy of the object map as a compressed sparse column matrix

Return type:

csc_matrix

property shape: tuple[int, int]¶
class phenoscope.core.accessors.ObjectMask(image_handler)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class provides access to the object map as a boolean array form and creates a way for binary operations to alter objects.

Note

Changes to the ObjectMask array will reset the labeling of the ObjectMap objects.

__getitem__(key)[source]¶

Returns a copy of the binary object mask in array form

__init__(image_handler)[source]¶

Initiallizes the ObjectMask object.

Parameters:

image_handler – (ImageHandler) The parent ImageHandler that the ObjectMask belongs to.

__setitem__(key, value: ndarray)[source]¶

Sets values of the object mask to value and resets the labeling in the map

Parameters:

value (ndarray)

copy() → ndarray[source]¶

Returns a copy of the binary object mask

Return type:

ndarray

reset()[source]¶
show(ax: ~matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes | None = None, figsize: str | None = None, cmap: str = 'tab20', title: str | None = None) -> (<class 'matplotlib.figure.Figure'>, <class 'matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes'>)[source]¶

Display the boolean object mask with matplotlib.

Calls object_map linked by the image handler

Parameters:

  • ax (Axes | None) – (plt.Axes) Axes object to use for plotting.

  • figsize (str | None) – (Tuple[int, int]): Figure size in inches.

  • cmap (str) – (str, optional) Colormap to use.

  • title (str | None) – (str) a title for the plot
